#Text=Tan-Che-Qua
#Text=Porcelain sculpture of a western lady holding a child , Rijksmuseum
#Text=Tan-Che-Qua
#Text=( alternatively Tan Chitqua or Tan Chetqua ) ( c. 1728 – �1796 ) was a Chinese artist who visited England from 1769 to 1772 . [ 1 ]
#Text=He exhibited his work at the Royal Academy in 1770 , and his clay models became fashionable in London for a short period .
#Text=He returned to China in 1772 .
#Text=After the merchant Loum Kiqua in 1756-7 , and the Christian convert Michael Shen Fuzong in 1687 , Tan-Che-Qua is one of the earliest Chinese people known to have visited England .
#Text=Career
#Text=Tan-Che-Qua was probably born in Guangdong in China .
#Text=He became an artist and clay modeller in Canton , making clay portrait figures . [ 1 ]
#Text=In his middle years , Tan-Che-Qua arrived in London from Canton on 11 August 1769 on the East Indiaman Horsendon . [ 2 ]
#Text=The Chinese authorities had given him permission to travel to Batavia ( now Jakarta ) , but he went to England instead .
#Text=He lived in lodgings on the Strand , where he worked as a clay modeler , creating busts for 10 guineas and small statuettes for 15 guineas . [ 1 ] [ 3 ] [ 4 ]
#Text=One of the few known surviving examples of his work is a figurine of physician Anthony Askew , held by the Royal College of Physicians .

#Text=The Museum of London has another attributed to Tan-Che-Qua of the London merchant Thomas Todd ; the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam has one of Dutch merchant Andreas Everardus van Braam Houckgeest ; and one of David Garrick is in a private collection [ 1 ] , which is confirmed not out of his hand but another Chinese modeler working in Canton in the 1730s .
#Text=He attended an audience with George III and Queen Charlotte . [ 1 ]
#Text=He also attended meetings at the Royal Academy of Arts and exhibited work there in 1770 .
#Text=He was included in a group portrait of the Royal Academicians by Johann Zoffany .

#Text=A portrait of Tan-Che-Qua , thought to be the one exhibited by John Hamilton Mortimer at the annual exhibition of the Incorporated Society of Artists in 1771 , is held by the Hunterian Museum at the Royal College of Surgeons in London . [ 5 ]
#Text=The portrait was misidentified as Wang-y-tong , another Chinese visitor to London in the 1770s , who attended meetings of the Royal Society . [ 6 ]
#Text=He was also sketched by Charles Grignion the Younger .
#Text=He boarded the East Indiaman Grenville in March 1771 intending to return to China .
#Text=After a series of accidents the crew took against him , he disembarked at Deal , Kent . [ 2 ]
#Text=He returned to China in 1772 .
#Text=The Gentleman 's Magazine reported that he committed suicide in Canton in the mid-1790s .
#Text=According to the RKD he died in Guangzhou in 1796 . [ 7 ]
#Text=Legacy

#Text=Sir William Chambers used his name – Tan Chet-qua – for the narrator of his Explanatory Discourse by Tan Chet-qua , of Quang-Chew-fu , Gent . , an appendix to the second edition ( 1773 ) of his book on Chinese gardening , Dissertation on Oriental Gardening ( 1772 ) , a fanciful elaboration of contemporary English ideas about the naturalistic style of gardening in China . [ 8 ]
